Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my phone, my thumb hovering over the “Buy Now” button for the Nintendo my son had been dreaming about for months. He’d been so patient, saving up his allowance, and I’d promised—sworn, even—that I’d make up the difference and order it today. I could already picture his face lighting up, the way he’d run to tell his friends, the pride in being able to keep my word as a parent. 

But just as I was about to confirm the purchase, my work phone buzzed urgently. The hospital’s ICU. A life-support machine was flashing critical fault codes, and the nurse’s voice was tight with panic. I was the only one on call with the expertise to fix it. If I didn’t go now, someone’s life could be at risk. 

My heart pounded. My son’s happiness, our family’s stability, my promise—on one side. On the other, the weight of responsibility, the knowledge that my skills could mean the difference between life and death. I felt torn in two, paralyzed by the impossible choice, as both worlds demanded all of me at once.
